description: From Old French galentine, galantine, variant of galatine, from Latin gelāta (“frozen”) + Old French -ine. Compare gelatin.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A spiced, thickened sauce served with fish or poultry. [from 14th c.]
examples: ‘Have some galantine. I'm going to. Your sole's cold.’

entries.meaning: A dish of boned, often stuffed meat (or fish) that has been boiled, and is served cold with its jelly. [from 18th c.]
